Context:
Program Name: Civil Engineering Technology
Code: T164
Credential: Ontario College Advanced Diploma
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: January, September
Domestic Tuition: $3,978.00
International Tuition: $18,015.00
Program Availability: Fall 2024 - Open, Winter 2025 - Open, Spring 2025 - Not Available
Location: Casa Loma Campus
Method of Study: Full-time
Centre: Construction & Engineering Technologies
School: Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management
Program Description: A three-year advanced diploma program that focuses on the planning, design, and construction of roads, bridges, tunnels, subdivisions, buildings, municipal services, and heavy infrastructure.
Courses: Designing reinforced concrete structures, storm, water and sanitary systems, roads, steel-framed structures; interpreting construction drawings and specifications through extensive practical training from project drawing sets; estimating, bidding, scheduling, and managing/supervising projects using the latest software; health and safety, site management, and quality management on construction sites; risk analysis and value analysis for construction projects; legal aspects of construction.
Experiential Learning: Available in Year 3 through a Divisional Select process.
Related Programs: Construction Engineering Technology (T105), Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) (T312), Construction Engineering Technician (T161).
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Civil Engineering Technology Program T164 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information on a construction program offered at a college, including the following facts:

1. The program covers risk analysis and value analysis for construction projects, legal aspects of construction contracts, and business management techniques.
2. Students are required to complete semester 2 in the summer after enrolling to continue into semester 3 in the fall.
3. Summer employment opportunities are encouraged in the civil and construction sectors for students through the Industry Liaison Office.
4. Co-op placement is offered after semester 5 for eligible students, with a term of 8–12 months. Students selected for co-op go for placement in the winter semester after completing semester 5 and do their semester 6 the following winter semester.
5. Graduates will have skills related to civil infrastructure projects design, construction, and maintenance and be prepared for employment in various organizations such as government agencies, contractors, sub-contractors, developers, engineering consulting firms, construction quality-control companies, cement and other construction materials manufacturing facilities, aggregate quarries, surveying companies, concrete plants, and asphalt plants.
6. Roles within these firms may include structural design assistant, assistant site superintendent, assistant project coordinator, project planner/scheduler, estimator, project monitor, quality control technician, project surveyor, municipal inspector, project permits & approvals coordinator, construction claims specialist, construction sales specialist, construction safety specialist, and quantity surveyor.
7. Canada's construction industry is essential to the construction and maintenance of residential and commercial buildings as well as infrastructure projects and has plans for increased spending in the coming years.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Civil Engineering Technology Program T164 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The federal government plans to increase infrastructure spending in the coming years, creating opportunities for graduates in the Construction Management field. Graduates with a Diploma can transition into the Honours Bachelor of Technology (Construction Management) degree program at this college, specifically T317. Here are the required courses for the first five semesters:

Semester 1:
- CIVL 1010: Introduction to Civil Engineering Technology
- CIVL 1011: Surveying 1
- CIVL 1012: Civil Engineering Materials
- CIVL 1141: Introduction to AutoCad 1
- PHY 1025: Introduction to Physics
- COMM 2000: Communicating Across Contexts
- MATH 1156: Mathematics for Civil Engineering Technology 1

Semester 2:
- CIVL 1013: Law for Civil Engineering Technology
- CIVL 1014: Introduction to Health and Safety
- CIVL 1015: Statics
- CIVL 1085: Land Use Planning & Regulations
- CIVL 2063: Estimating Civil Projects
- MATH 1166: Mathematics for Civil Engineering Technology 2
- GNED: General Education Elective (select one)

Semester 3:
- CIVL 2021: Planning & Scheduling for Civil Projects
- CIVL 2059: Introduction to AutoCad 2
- CIVL 2079: Strengths of Materials
- CIVL 2080: Surveying 2
- CIVL 2081: Principles and Practices of Construction 1 – Buildings
- COMM 1113: Professional Communications for Building Technologies
- MATH 2066: Mathematics for Civil Engineering Technology 3

Semester 4:
- CIVL 2082: Introduction to Soil Mechanics
- CIVL 2083: Introduction to Fluid Mechanics
- CIVL 2084: Professional Workplace Skills
- CIVL 2085: Principles and Practices of Construction 2 – Highways, Bridges, and Earthworks
- CIVL 2086: Engineering Economics
- CIVL 3028: Introduction to GIS Technology
- GNED: General Education Elective (select one)

Semester 5:
- CIVL 2045: Site Management for Civil Projects

There are future study options available for individual graduates at various universities.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Civil Engineering Technology Program T164 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered in semester 6 and 7 of the civil engineering program at the college. Some of these courses include:

* CIVL 2045: Site Management for Civil Projects
* CIVL 3026: Engineering Technical Report
* CIVL 3034: Introduction to AutoDesk Civil 3D
* CIVL 3086: Structural Design 1 - Steel
* CIVL 3087: Introduction to Municipal Engineering Technology
* CIVL 3088: Construction Equipment Management
* MATH 3066: Introduction to Statistical Inference
* CIVL 3039: Rehabilitation of Civil Infrastructure Projects
* CIVL 3089: Introduction to Traffic and Highway Engineering
* CIVL 3090: Civil Construction Quality Management
* CIVL 3091: Structural Design 2 – Concrete
* CIVL 3092: Introduction to Environmental Engineering Technology

There is also a mention of an elective course, GNED, that students can select one from. The program learning outcomes for the civil engineering graduates include: developing and using strategies for professional growth, complying with health and safety practices, completing duties in accordance with contractual obligations, promoting sustainable practices, facilitating collaboration among team members, collecting and analyzing technical data, using industry-specific technologies, participating in design and modeling phases of projects, contributing to scheduling, coordination, and cost estimation, and performing quality control.

There is a note for students about taking COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000 if required based on their placement test results. This course does not count towards graduation requirements but students will be charged for it, and they can find more information at the Assessment Centre.

Context:
The text provides information about a civil engineering program offered at George Brown College. Here are some key factual details extracted from the text:

* The civil engineering projects in the program are managed using principles of construction project management.
* Students coordinate and perform quality control testing, evaluate equipment, materials, and methods used in implementing and completing civil engineering projects.
* Domestic tuition for the first two semesters is $3,978.00 (estimated).
* International tuition for the first two semesters is $18,015.00 (estimated).
* Additional costs beyond tuition are subject to change and include materials, student service, ancillary fees, and books.
* Financial assistance is available through OSAP for eligible applicants.
* Applicants need an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent, grade 12 English (C or U), and grade 11 Math (U) or grade 12 Math (C or U). Mature students may take the Admissions Assessment for English and Math or upgrade to achieve the necessary credits.
* Meeting minimum admission requirements does not guarantee admission to the program.

There is no explicit mention of a specific year or start date for the program in the text, but it does indicate that fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2024/Civil Engineering Technology Program T164 | George Brown College2024.txt

Context: The Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management offers a program with specific laptop and Internet requirements for students. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System. The recommended laptop specifications include Windows 10 Home 64-bit English operating system, a 9th Generation Intel Core i7-9750H processor, 16GB (2x8GB DDR4 2666MHz) memory, 256GB M.2 PCIe NVMe Solid State Drive (Boot) + 1TB 5400 rpm 2.5" SATA Hard Drive (Storage), NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2060 6GB GDDR6 display card, and 802.11ac WiFi and Bluetooth connectivity, among other features. The purchase of a Mac laptop is not recommended. For more information, contact the Angelo DelZotto School of Construction Management at 416-415-5000 ext. 4398 or construction\_eng@georgebrown.ca during office hours from 8 a.m. to 4 p.m., room E228. Applicants may be required to have grades higher than the minimum requirements stated. Course exemptions are available with college or university credits, and more information can be found on the Transfer Guide page. International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
